people.name: ChrisÂ  Perdriau
people.bio: Chris is a CS student at Oregon State University studying HCI and psychology. He is interested in making technology more inclusive for underserved communities.

people.name: Anael Kuperwajs Cohen
people.bio: Anael is a CS and applied mathematics and statistics double major with a cognitive science concentration at Macalester College. She is interested in breaking down barriers for women and other minorities within the field of CS by pursuing a career in CS education.

people.name: Mina Tari
people.bio: Mina is PhD student in the Information School exploring women of color's experiences in introductory computing courses. She's a homegrown UW student, coming from the Informatics and Gender, Women, and Sexuality Studies programs. Mina works with Amy and the lab to apply a critical feminist lens to questions regarding equity in computing education.

people.name: Jenny Liang
people.bio: Jenny is an undergrad studying computer science and informatics. She is working with Amy to study how to use explicit programming strategies to improve collaboration and learning of developers.

people.name: Emilia Borisova
people.bio: Emilia is an undergraduate student pursuing Informatics. She is interested in computing education and is helping with Neil's research on understanding the personal and interpersonal factors influencing computing career choices.

people.name: Stefania Druga
people.bio: Stefania Druga is the creator of http://cognimates.me, a platform for AI education for kids, which started as her Master Thesis at MIT Media Lab. Currently is a Ph.D. student at the University of Washington. She has observed in longitudinal studies how 450 children from 7 countries are growing up with AI and how hey can acquire AI literacy concepts through creative learning activities. She is co-advised by Benjamin Mako Hill.

people.name: Chandrashree Karnani
people.bio: Chandrashree is studying data science in the Informatics program. She's interested in how data can be used to make informed decisions. She's helping with Yim's work on machine learning literacy.

people.name: Zoshua Colah
people.bio: Zoshua is an Informatics major specializing in UX Design and Data Science who spends his time helping freshman and sophomore students learn more about tech.

people.name: Neil Ryan
people.bio: Neil is a PhD student in Computer Science and Engineering, curiously pursuing connections between debugging, self-regulation, meta-cognition, tacit knowledge, and programming strategies.

people.name: Christina Zhang
people.dept: Computer Science and the Information School
people.bio: Christina is an undergraduate majoring in Computer Science and Informatics. She's working on supporting research on intelligent programmin tutors.

people.name: Matt Davidson
people.bio: Matt is a doctoral in measurement & statistics who has collaborated closely on the lab's work on assessments of programming skills.

people.name: Meron Solomon
people.bio: Meron is an undergraduate who helped design and teach an innovative new computing course to Upward Bound students in 2019.

people.name: Patrick Old
people.bio: Patrick was an undergraduate studying Informatics and Oceanography. He worked on a project to observe his growth as a teacher via participant observation.

people.name: Andrew Hu
people.bio: Andrew is a CS & Education double major interested in pedagogical techniques and student motivation in CS Ed.

people.name: Alannah Oleson
people.bio: Alannah is a PhD student in the Information School, broadly interested in the learning and teaching of inclusive software design methods. Before joining UW, she studied gender-inclusive software at Oregon State University.

people.name: Yim Register
people.bio: Yim is a PhD student in the Information School, broadly interested in machine learning literacy. Before joining UW, they studied cognitive science at the University of Rochester.

people.name: Jane Quichocho
people.bio: Jane helped the lab on various learning to code projects.

people.name: William Kwok
people.bio: William is an undergraduate in the Information School. He supported the lab's research on programming tutors by advancing design, development, instruction, and ideation relation to expressing agency when learning computing online.

people.name: Harshitha Akkaraju
people.bio: Harshitha is an undergraduate in the Information School. She supported the lab's research on programming tutors by advancing design, development, instruction, and ideation relation to expressing agency when learning computing online.

people.name: Laura Vonessen
people.bio: For her qualifying exam, Laura led a project on faculty professional development for teaching accessibility, sponsored by AccessComputing, with help from Saba Kawas.

people.name: Rahul Banerjee
people.bio: Rahul works in the Center for Game Science and has worked with the lab on programming by demonstration systems for creating interactive games.

people.name: Kristen Shinohara
people.bio: Kristen was a PhD student advised by Jake Wobbrock and Wanda Pratt. She worked with Amy multiple times as a teaching assistant, and later on nationwide survey of higher education instruction on accessibility. She graduated in 2017 and joined the faculty at Rochester Institute of Technology.

people.name: Annie Yan
people.bio: Annie is a Ph.D. student in the Information School working with Carol Palmer. Annie worked with Amy on predicting dropout in a coding tutorial.

people.name: Ada Kim
people.bio: Ada was a Ph.D. student in the Information School working with Katie Davis. Ada worked with Amy on a pedagogical analysis of coding tutorials as part of a research practicum.

people.name: Saba Kawas
people.bio: Saba is a PhD student in the Information School working with Katie Davis. Saba worked with Amy on a nationwide survey of the teaching of accessibility in higher education in the United States.

people.name: Benjamin Xie
people.bio: Benji is a PhD student in the Information School interested in learning analytics for computing education. Before joining UW, he studied App Inventor and MOOCs with Hal Abelson at MIT.

people.name: Greg Nelson
people.bio: Greg is a PhD student in Computer Science and Engineering. He's interested in HCI and computing education broadly, and has focused on programming language learning and augmented and virtual reality.
achievements: ACM ICER John Henry Best Paper Award (2018)

people.name: Kyle Thayer
people.bio: Kyle was a PhD student in Computer Science and Engineering, co-advised by Katharina Reinecke. His dissertation investigated barriers to learning to code knowledge through bootcamps, developed a novel theory of API knowledge, and contributed a new way to mine the web for API usage patterns. He is now a Lecturer at the University of Washington Information school, where he continues investigating the intersection of diversity and computing education as a teacher and researcher.
achievements: Lecturer, The Information School, University of Washington (2019-present)

people.name: Amanda Swearngin
people.bio: Amanda was a Ph.D. student in Computer Science & Engineeering. Her dissertation contributed design tools that leverage program analysis, program synthesis, constraint solving, and machine learning. She is now a Research Engineer at Apple in Accessibility and Machine Learning.

people.name: Dastyni Loksa
people.bio: Dastyni was a Ph.D. student in the the Information School. His dissertation focused on problem solving in programming, with a particular focus on self-regulated learning, spanning the fields of HCI and computing education. He is now tenure-track faculty at Towson University, teaching CS and preparing CS teachers.

people.name: Zakariya Dehlawi
people.bio: Zak was a Ph.D. student in the the Information School, co-advised by Amy Ko and Barbara Endicott-Popovsky. He received his Master of Science in Security Informatics from Johns Hopkins in 2011 and bachelor degrees in Computer Engineering and Political Science from the University of Washington in 2009. His research focused on security practices in software teams and organizations. After leaving the Ph.D. program, he worked as Senior Security Engineer at Security Innovation, Inc.

people.name: Paul Luo Li
people.bio: Paul Luo Li was a Ph.D. student in the Information School at the University of Washington, advised by Amy. His dissertation work focused on software engineering expertise. After graduating, Paul continued his full-time role as a Senior Data Scientist at Microsoft.

people.name: Michael J. Lee
people.bio: Michael Lee was a PhD student in the Information School at the University of Washington, advised by Amy Ko. His dissertation work focused on educational programming games, and game design factors that affect learning and engagement. After graduating, Mike began as an Assistant Professor at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Information Systems.
achievements: Assistant Professor, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Information Systems (2015-present)
ACM ICER John Henry Best Paper Award (2013)

people.name: Brian Burg
people.bio: Brian Burg was a Ph.D. student in the CSE Department at the University of Washington, co-advised with Mike Ernst. His dissertation focused on web development productivity tools to support debugging, program comprehension, and reverse engineering tool. After graduating, Brian joined Apple's WebKit team.

people.name: Kayur Patel
people.bio: Kayur Patel was a Ph.D. student in Computer Science at the University of Washington, co-advised by James Fogarty and James Landay. His dissertation focused on tools for supporting the development of machine learned classifiers.

people.name: Parmit K. Chilana
people.bio: Parmit K. Chilana was a PhD student at the Information School co-advised by Jake Wobbrock. Her dissertation focused on crowdsourced help systems and organizational factors in gathering and understanding user feedback about software. After graduating, Parmit began as an Assistant Professor at the University of Waterloo.
achievements: Assistant Professor, Simon Fraser University, Computer Science (2016-present)
Assistant Professor, University of Waterloo, Management Sciences, (2013-2016)
Canadian Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council (SSHRC) Doctoral Award (2009)

people.name: Roshanak Zilouichian
people.bio: Roshanak was a postdoc in the lab working on collaboration, consensus, information visualization, and creativity support tools. After completing her postdoc, she began as a Data Scientist at Microsoft.

people.name: Harrison Kwik
people.bio: Harrison was an undergraduate in computer science interested in equitable learning of computing. He's supported the lab's research on programming tutors while independently investigating the experiences of CS transfer students. After graduating, he began a Ph.D. at Northwestern University.

people.name: Leanne Hwa
people.bio: Leanne was an Informatics undergraduate interested in computing education, mentorship, and identity. She supported the lab's research on programming tutors while independently investigating the role of informal computing mentors amongst south Seattle teens.
achievements: UW Husky 100, recognizing top UW undergrad and graduates (2019)

people.name: Alex Tan
people.bio: Alex is an Informatics undergraduate in computing education. He supported the lab's research on programming tutors.

people.name: Michael Beswetherick
people.bio: Michael helped engineer Gidget while an Informatics undergrad. He now helps engineer NY Times.

people.name: Andre Stackhouse
people.bio: Andre helped engineer Gidget while an Informatics undergrad, then at Code.org. He now helps engineer Bing at Microsoft.

people.name: Polina Charters
people.bio: Polina was a Psychology student who helped develop many of the instruments for our studies of Gidget, and also ran a study evaluating attitude shifts among adults who played Gidget. She went on to our Masters in HCI+Design.

people.name: Fanny Luor
people.bio: Fanny was a Design student who illustrated all of the art for Gidget. She went on to design and illustrate at Airbnb and Dropbox.

people.name: Nadav Ashkenazi
people.bio: Nadav was a Computer Science and Informatics student who helped engineer Gidget. He went on to Google to help build Earth VR.

people.name: Staffan Hellman
people.bio: Staffan was an Informatics student who helped engineer Gidget. He went on to work at Weebly.

people.name: Steven Raden
people.bio: Steven was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer Gidget. He went on to work at IBM as a UX designer.

people.name: William Menten-Weil
people.bio: Liam was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer our work on programming problem solving tutors, focusing specifically on an advanced tutorial authoring interface.

people.name: Dakota Miller
people.bio: Dakota was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer our work on programming problem solving tutors, focusing specifically on an advanced tutorial authoring interface.

people.name: Alexandra Rowell
people.bio: Alex was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer our work on programming problem solving tutors, focusing specifically on how to present expert identity.

people.name: Xing Zhang
people.bio: Xing was an Electrical Engineering student that helped evaluate Feedlack, our verification tool for finding missing feedback in interfaces.

people.name: Stephen Ip
people.bio: Stephen was an Informatics student who helped with our studies of bug triage.

people.name: Charlie Tran
people.bio: Charlie was an Informatics student who helped with our studies of bug triage. He went on to become a program manager at Microsoft.

people.name: Valentina Ferrari
people.bio: Valentina was an Informatics student who helped with our studies of bug triage. She went on to become a UX designer at Adobe.

people.name: Neeraja Duriseti
people.bio: Neeraja was an Informatics and Applied Math student who helped analyze a corpus of tens of thousands of news articles about software failures.

people.name: Bryan Dosono
people.bio: Bryan was an Informatics student who helped analyze a corpus of tens of thousands of news articles about software failures. He went on to do a Ph.D. in Information Science at Syracuse University.

people.name: Padma Vaithyam
people.bio: Padma was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer Gidget. She went on to Microsoft as a software engineer.

people.name: Diana Jiang
people.bio: Diana was an Informatics student who helped design and engineer Gidget.

people.name: Casey Hickerson
people.bio: Casey was a doctoral student that studied design practices.

projects.name: Programming language learning
projects.description: Robust understanding of a programming language is a key foundation for being able to create software. My lab investigates what it means to know a programming language, invents and evaluates educational technologies that streamline learning of a programming language, and invents and evaluates assessments that help identify what learners do and do not know about a programming language.
projects.impact: This work has shaped the curriculum designed by Code.org, which is used by thousands of U.S. teachers and hundreds of thousands of youth. Gidget has been played by thousands of people online, in summer camps, and in high schools. It has directly informed the design of Code.org's Code Studio and Apple's Swift Playgrounds.

projects.name: Programming problem solving
projects.description: A critical part of creating software is being able to understand programming problems, identify solutions to solve them, and systematically implement, verify, and debug programs, and avoid mistakes throughout. My lab investigates effective ways of learning these skills, and orchestrating them with self-regulation, process, and strategy.
projects.impact: This work has shaped the curriculum and teacher professional development designed by Code.org, particularly, which is used by thousands of U.S. teachers and hundreds of thousands of youth.

projects.name: Broadening participation in computing
projects.description: The world is full of structural barriers to developing interest in and learning computing. My lab investigates these barriers and ways to eradicate them, including issues around accessibility, mentorship, culture, identity, and resources, with the goal of increasing the diversity of people in computing disciplines.
projects.impact: We apply our work and others to working directly with local communities to make change, including lowering barriers to transfer students at the University of Washington, connecting with marginalized communities in South Seattle, teaching in the University of Washington's Upward Bound program, and developing statewide coalitions to ensure CS for All.

projects.name: Teaching inclusive design
projects.description: Design should work for everyone. We investigate ways of teaching design that ensure that designers, and especially software developers, understand how to create software that is inclusive, especially to people with disabilities.
projects.impact: This work has impacted the teaching of many higher education HCI educators.

projects.name: API learning
projects.description: Most modern software is built by reusing APIs, libraries, frameworks, and other code that others have carefully designed and tested. Unfortunately, such reuse often requires robust learning of API features. My lab investigates barriers to learning API's robustly and invents more effective ways of learning APIs.
projects.impact: Findings on coding bootcamps have been discussed broadly on Reddit and Hacker News [1, 2], including a blog post read nearly 10,000 times in four days.

projects.name: Software engineering expertise
projects.description: Engineering production software requires far more than knowing how to code. We've investigated the skills that are required for developers to be great engineers, including not only technical skills, but communication, collaboration, design, and business skills as well.
projects.impact: This work has been read widely in industry, including by product teams at Microsoft, Adobe, Google, and ABB. Our research on software engineering experience have been used to frame soft skills instruction in the Academy for Software Engineering curriculum in New York and have also reached over 10,000 academics and software engineers through an ACM Learning Center Webinar.

projects.name: Understanding machine learning
projects.description: While most programs are still written by developers, many are now built by gathering large amounts of data and automatically creating machine learned programs. My lab is investigating the immense comprehension challenges imposed by these probablistic forms of program behavior, as well as the literacy required to understand how they are shaping program behavior and society.
projects.impact: Our work on understanding machine learning has indirectly shaped several of the tools used in industry to develop and debug machine learned programs.

projects.name: User interface mining
projects.description: User interfaces are structured documents, allowing us to analyze, reverse engineer, and transform them. My lab is applying techniques from program analysis and synthesis to automatically transform interfaces to be more accessible, usable, and useful.
projects.impact: Our work on interface mining has been replicated in several indusry projects focused on supporting interface development.

projects.name: Theory and methods
projects.description: Studying programming is hard. We invent new methods for studying programming, and reflect on the science of studying programming, to help accelerate progress on improving it.
projects.impact: Our work on research methods is widely read by new Ph.D. students across computer science to inform how they evaluate new developer tools and how they use theory.

projects.name: Literature reviews and surveys
projects.description: A critical part of scholarly progress is synthesizing and explaining what we've learned. Sometimes this results in robust discussions of prior work; other times we go further, publishing standalone papers and book chapters that help newcomers make sense of what we know.
projects.impact: Our surveys are widely-cited and used by doctoral students to quickly learn about the state of the art and knowledge.

projects.name: Understanding program behavior
projects.description: Finding and fixing bugs is challenging. My lab studies debugging and invents tools that it make program understanding easier by combining human intelligence with machine intelligence.
projects.impact: Our studies on program understanding and ideas for program understanding tools was partially the basis of the Debugger Canvas plugin for Visual Studio. Frictionary was used in one of the features in AnswerDash, the company I co-founded based on my CAREER grant. Timelapse is being upstreamed to WebKit and will likely appear in the Safari Web Inspector developer tools. Many of the ideas in Barista have made it into more modern environments like Scratch and Greenfoot. The Whyline has impacted several projects, including Microsoft's IntelliTrace feature in Visual Studio, it's Debugger Canvas Visual Studio plugin, and the record-replay features in it's latest Chakra JavaScript runtime. Other projects, including Mozilla's rr and the Elm Debugger have also incorporated time-travel debugging features. None have implemented the full vision of Whyline's interface or analysis, but many are getting close, as the infrastructure for execution tracing, record/replay, and dynamic analysis are becoming scalable enough for production use.

projects.name: Bug triage and user feedback
projects.description: When software gets shared with the world, helping people use it, and understanding their struggles in using it, are critical to improving it. My lab has studied challenges in gathering user feedback, and invented several tools that both provide better technical support, while also gathering data to improve software.
projects.impact: Lemonaid, our crowdsourced help tool, was the basis for AnswerDash, a company that I co-founded with Jacob Wobbrock and Parmit Chilana that offers an instant self-service answers product for web applications and e-commerce sites. The company has impacted other company's product offerings, including Zendesk's self-service technologies.

projects.name: End-user software engineering
projects.description: Many people write code to support their own work (e.g., teachers write grading spreadsheets, scientists write scripts to process data, people automate their homes). In these end-user programming contexts, people face many of the same challenges that arise in professional software engineering, just without the same incentives to be systematic in testing, debugging, and maintenance. Our work has investigated these contexts and invented tools to support them.
projects.impact: Our work on end-user software engineering has inspired hundreds of commercial tools for supporting end-user programming and impacted research efforts in professional software engineering.

travel.title: University of Pennsylvania, Computer and Information Science Colloqium
Carnegie Mellon University, HCI Institute Seminar
University of Colorado Boulder Information Science Colloquium
ICER 2020
travel.details: The 2020 ACM International Computing Education Research conference, held online. I was the junior program chair and led the planning of the event.

travel.title: PL+HCI Swimmer School
travel.details: A summer school that brought together perspectives on HCI and programming languages research. I gave the first invited talk on how to discover things about programming by making and evaluating tools.

travel.title: ISAT/DARPA End-User Mashup Workshop
travel.details: This brought together experts in end-user programming and 'low-code' programming to inform future research opportunities in the U.S. government. I contributed as one of the experts.

travel.title: APL LGBTQ+ Panel
travel.details: This brought together a diverse panel of LGBTQ people in science and engineering to discuss their experiences in academia, research, and engineering. I served as a panelist. The panel was recorded.

travel.title: CSTA 2020
travel.details: The 2020 CSTA Conference brought together CS teachers from across North America for two days, online. I attended several sessions and met many teachers through the random chat feature.

travel.title: CRA-E Annual Meeting
travel.details: I joined the Computing Research Associatin's Education board; this was my first full board meeting.

travel.title: SIGCSE 2020
travel.details: I traveled to Portland, fully masked and distance, ready to speak in about seven sessions. The conference was canceled the morning of the first day.
